title: Thursday, 14th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning -- welcome to Markets Live

PM11:02am

PM11:02am

Notice that we no longer have to write "specimen" over the note?

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Why did the press always have to do that?

PM11:03am

It was the dumbest thing

PM11:03am

Was in case someone copied it

11:03 am
PM11:03am

As if a forger couldn't access their own original note

PM11:03am

I don't like these new plastic notes

PM11:03am

They don't fold properly

11:04 am
PM11:04am

And we're not supposed to call them plastic, cos they're "polymer" apparently.

PM11:04am

Which in my book is plastic

PM11:04am

But yeah I'm aware that there are natural as well as synthetic polymers

11:04 am
PM11:04am

whatever

BE11:04am

Um, so hang on. Has the Forgery and Counterfeiting Act 1981 been repealed?

PM11:05am

Omg smile

11:04 am
BE11:05am

Because that's the reason you have to put "specimen" across banknotes.

PM11:05am

Dunno

PM11:05am

So i've just broken the law

11:05 am
BE11:05am

I think you have!

BE11:05am

http://www.bankofe...repro_app_form.pdf

BE11:06am

Don't worry, I'll visit you in Wormwood.

11:07 am
undefined
PM11:07am

John-Paul Crutchley mentioned on the right

PM11:07am

It is of course the Crock anniversary

11:07 am
PM11:07am

And taht was the reason I was a little late this morning opening the sessoin

PM11:07am

Was glancing at the session from 10 years ago

PM11:08am

Bloody chaos

11:07 am
PM11:08am

https://ftalphavil...tslive/2007-09-14/

PM11:08am

But we don't look back much, here

PM11:08am

So let's get on with today's news...

11:08 am
undefined
PM11:08am

Next!

PM11:09am

You'll want to go through the statement Bryce

11:08 am
PM11:09am

Of course

PM11:09am

But can i just point out that this looks like further evidence of poor market structure

BE11:09am

.............. arguable.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

It's next. It's a top tier Footsie firm

PM11:09am

It's analysed to the nth degree

PM11:10am

And then it moves 11 per cent cos Wolfson has a bright tone to his statement

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Well, that's the thing. The figures are much as expected, which they should be as there was a pre-close update..

BE11:10am

There's nothing specific on current trading.

PM11:11am

They've raised guidance a tad, tho

11:10 am
PM11:11am

But an eleven per cent move?!?

BE11:11am

The guidance bump, also, was pretty much expected as it was previously lowballed in case the efforts to fix Directory failed.

PM11:11am

hmm

11:11 am
BE11:12am

So, as you say, it's the tone. " whilst the retail environment remains tough, our prospects going forward appear somewhat less challenging than they did six months ago."

BE11:12am

But also the buyback.

BE11:12am

Which is tiny, but is a signal.

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Statement here btw https://www.invest...1709140700066975Q/

BE11:13am

And it seems the market still trusts Wolfson to figure out when to spend Next's (still fairly impressive, though much reduced) cash generation on buybacks and when to give them as specials.

PM11:13am

Is there fresh reason not to trust the chap?

11:13 am
BE11:14am

We used to consider him some kind of Delphic guru.

BE11:14am

Then suddenly we didn't.

BE11:14am

Anyway, buyback is only £53m and is "at some point during the second half, subject to the prevailing share price and market conditions"

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Which is largely because Next's already committed to dropping £257m on specials.

BE11:15am

The earnings guidance upgrade is only a 1% bump to £687-747m and was already in consensus

BE11:16am

Which is £716m as per Bloomberg.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

So .... yes, maybe. The sellside had this down already. There's nothing in here except a slightly warmer tone and a signal from management that the shares look cheap, which the buyside has taken to with enthusiasm.

BE11:18am

And while today's share price move looks dramatic, it just resets Next back to the sector average (which is already at fairly distressed due to too much space and Amazonification and all those things we talk about endlessly).

BE11:18am

Morgan Stanley:

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Based on existing consensus forecasts and last night's closing price, Next is trading on 11.3x Cal 2018 earnings, 8.6x EBITDA, with a 3.9% Dividend Yield. This compares with a UK General Retail sector trading on 12.1x, 7.6x and 4.5% respectively.

BE11:19am

And I'm not sure there's a lot more to say, but that fact won't stop me cutting and pasting.

BE11:19am

Barclays.

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Next reported 1H results this morning with PBT of £309.4m slightly ahead of consensus £301m and roughly in line with our £310.1m. In terms of segments, Next retail operating profits came in c.6% below our estimates (£89.5m vs. £95.5m – c. 33% yoy decline), and Directory came in 3.5% ahead of our estimates (£217.1m vs. £209.8m – c. 6% yoy growth). Overall operating profits of £325.2m (-9.3% yoy) were roughly in line with our estimate of £326.4m, implying operating margins of 17.2% vs. 18.6% last year (greater than 130bps yoy decline). The company declared an interim dividend of 53p per share, in line with last year. On a net basis, the company plans to close 8 stores during FY18 but increase net space by 1.1% (larger new stores). The profitability of the portfolio of stores opened or extended in the last 12 months is seeing an increase in payback to 28.6 months from the company's own threshold of 24 months. The main reason is failure of 5 stores to meet their targets after the extension and refit. Management mentioned that it had overestimated the uplift on sales that it could generate from the program and that these refits should have been budgeted from maintenance Cape rather than development CapEx. The company also upgraded its full year full price sales range to -2.0% to +1.5% from -3% to +0.5% previously (-0.25% at the midpoint vs. previous -1.25%). For the second half management expects -2.8% to +3.8%. New earnings per share guidance: range changed from -11.8% to -4.0% previously, to -10.9% to -3.1%(Now -7% at the midpoint vs. previous -7.9%). Profit before tax range changes from -13.9% to -6.4% to -13.1% to -5.5% (Now -9.3% at the midpoint vs. previous -10.2%). Barclays is at -10.6% and Bloomberg consensus is at -8.1%.

PM11:20am

(One other thing to mention: scrolling through the statement it's a perfect model of clear, well-organised presentation. Quite a few other companies could learn from this.)

BE11:21am

(Yeah, maybe. Though the counterpoint would be that some investors would like a bit more detail about Next's Directories business. The type of detail you expect from other comparable sub-prime lenders.)

11:21 am
PM11:21am

hehe

BE11:21am

And Citi.

BE11:22am

Implications — January 2018 consensus PBT likely to increase slightly — On the back of this statement we would expect consensus forecast to increase c.1% to reflect the updated guidance. For the record, we have a £696m Jan 2018E PBT (EPS 391.5p, -10.6% yoy). This assumes FY18e Next Brand sales -0.6% (LFL - 1.9%; split Retail -7.6%, Directory +5.6%), and 17.2% Next Brand EBIT margin (- 220bps yoy). This compares to company guidance for FY18 PBT of £680-740m.
 Neutral, target price 4,180p — Our 4,180p target price is based on an 11.2x PE multiple to FY18e EPS. This target equates to a c.10x EV/EBIT multiple and 8.1% dividend yield for the same forecast year.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

And Peel Hunt on the sector readacross.

BE11:23am

Next has become the third major retailer to upgrade forecasts this week, and it is clear to us that the doom and gloom surrounding the sector is overdone. Yes, the weather may have boosted recent sales but sustaining the good start to AW would mean reduced pressure to discount later in the season. Next, Primark and JD Sports# have all shown that the consumer will spend if the right
product and the right price is offered, and John Lewis has also suggested that fashion sales in particular have enjoyed the late-summer/early Autumn. The sector’s valuation suggests that
forecasts will come under pressure to the downside: we think the opposite is true and weeks like this will be commonplace as we move through the reporting season. Our top picks are B&M,
JD#, Supergroup, Card Factory, boohoo and McColl’s.

BE11:23am

We expect SuperGroup to impress at its CMD (25-26 Sep). boohoo should be upbeat on the 27th (upgrades expected) and Card Factory will re-emphasise its attractions on the 26th. B&M is our top pick: store visits confirm the notion that customers are trading down and it is well placed to take advantage.

11:23 am
SuperGroup PLC (SGP:LSE): Last: 1,569, up 5 (+0.32%), High: 1,572, Low: 1,558, Volume: 12.99k
Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 253.25, up 5 (+2.01%), High: 253.25, Low: 246.75, Volume: 1.36m
BE11:24am

And in terms of the large caps, M&S .....

11:24 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 338.80, up 14.3 (+4.41%), High: 341.00, Low: 328.70, Volume: 6.98m
BE11:24am

Which I think isn't scheduled to say anything until November.

BE11:26am

And has problems that have no parallel with Next, such as a food business that's on an expansion drive when LFL looks decidedly shaky.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Interesting note a few days ago from Morgan Stanley, suggesting M&S food was getting Deliveroo'd and that was a structural problem rather than a cyclical one.

BE11:26am

Anyway, that's enough Next.

undefined
11:26 am
PM11:27am

Actually, with you just mentioning food...

PM11:27am

Did you see this huge from on european grocers out from MOST today?

BE11:27am

No.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

THey've got rankings and maps for every european country

PM11:28am

Actually, now I look it's just about all pictures

PM11:28am

Not sure what the point is, but just interesting to leaf through

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Things like this

PM11:28am

BE11:28am

Geospacial analysis seems on trend right now. Someone in a research department figured out how to use Google Maps API, I guess.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

And read Kantar

BE11:29am

Well, yes. Also that.

PM11:29am

There you go -- ive usual placed it

11:29 am
PM11:29am

Wink smile

BE11:29am

Thumbs up

PM11:29am

https://ftalphavil...room/content/71526

11:29 am
undefined
BE11:29am

So, I was going to mention Interserve but there seems to be no appetite on the right.

BE11:30am

Only kidding! Profit warning. Again.

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Here's a tenner, which can be our pic of the day

Interserve PLC (IRV:LSE): Last: 71.99, down 80.26 (-52.72%), High: 90.00, Low: 68.75, Volume: 13.38m
BE11:30am

Both sides of the business. Construction and support services.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

Lack of market structure -- or just dreadful statement?

PM11:30am

Latter, obvs

BE11:31am

Truly dreadful. And it could be argued that the lack of market structure was reflected in the fact that Interserve had willing shareholders after its first dozen or so warnings.

11:31 am
PM11:32am

Short bad news here https://www.invest...1709140700056957Q/

BE11:32am

Yup. As of today, in addition to the core trading stuff, we also get Energy for Waste remaining an absolute nightmare.

BE11:32am

Timing and complexities mean final costs will "significantly exceed" the £160m currently provided for.

11:32 am
PM11:33am

Sheesh

BE11:33am

Indeed. Getting to the point where it would have been cheaper to just burn the money.

BE11:33am

Here comes Numis to summarise what's said.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

At the time of the interim results,
management alluded to a potential ‘hockey stick’ recovery in UK Support Services
driven by an anticipated improvement in the market. However, some shortfall in higher
margin discretionary work in particular has impacted the business, and we assume
this is maintained in H2 even with the benefit of cost reductions previously announced.
We therefore model the H1 EBIT run-rate continuing for the full year and into 2018. In
addition, the group points to a disappointing performance in UK Construction.

BE11:34am

Energy for Waste. We understand that the incremental issues have arisen from further
delays to commissioning. Whilst the group has not provided updated guidance in
regards to the final costs, reading between the lines we assume an incremental 10-20%
of the original provision. This would suggest a further c.£15-30m charge, and we model
the upper end of this range and include it as an exceptional in our 2017 forecasts. We
would note that for covenant purposes, the P&L impact of this exceptional is excluded
and the cash impact is anticipated to flow through in 2018.

BE11:34am

Forecasts. Based on the above, our 2017 and 2018 PBT forecasts fall 24% to
£78m and £88m, respectively. Furthermore, we now assume no dividend is paid in
2018 (previously DPS of 15p). With regards to net debt, driven by working capital
management, which is a lever management has alluded to, we forecast a 5% reduction
in net debt to £403m in 2017 and a 3% increase to £410m in 2018.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

That £78m looks hopeful given history. Peel Hunt's not confident enough to even put a forecast out.

BE11:36am

We have little choice but to suspend estimates at this stage as we have no insight into the quantum of trading issues and potential for resolution. If we were to assume that Equipment Services is trading in line (otherwise we would have been told) and extrapolate/interpret correctly, then there could be a c20%+ reduction to FY2017 PBT. This would imply interest cover c4x and ND/EBITDA c3x – very close to covenants.

PM11:36am

Goodness me

11:36 am
BE11:36am

We had expected closing average FY2017 net debt of c£500m, with closing net debt of £435m. This implied FY2017E ND/EBITDA 2.7x (covenant less than 3.0x) with Interest Cover 5.2x (covenant more than 3.5x). Management still expects to be within its banking covenants for FY2017, but this statement is probably based on the likelihood that the EfW cash costs will fall into 2018. Interserve has facilities of £640m, with a weighted expiry in April 2022.

PM11:37am

You know this business employs 80,000 people...

BE11:37am

Yep, it's huge, and can be seen as emblematic of the failure of state outsourcing.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Much as Carillion can, and Mitie, and Capita, all the others in this sector.

BE11:40am

When you're in a system that's hardwired to favour the bid that's least equipped to come in on budged, there really is no good in doing £3.5bn in sales (as Interserve does) because your margin is so thin that one miscalculation or overly optimistic tender puts you through your debt covenants.

BE11:40am

Stupid bloody sector.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Oh, and I guess we should note that the warning is post the CEO coming in at the start of September.

BE11:41am

It's a "oh my god!" rather than a kitchen sink.

BE11:42am

Have Canaccord.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

..... whenever it opens.

PM11:43am

...

BE11:44am

.... Ah! All that wait and it's blank!

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Brilliant

BE11:44am

BE11:44am

I can't disagree with any of that.

11:44 am
PM11:44am

hehehe

undefined
PM11:45am

Morrisons!

11:45 am
PM11:45am

Why is this down 5%

PM11:45am

I thought the figs were fine!

PM11:45am

I won't go on about market structure, but....

11:45 am
PM11:45am

Were expectations for Morrison really so high??

PM11:45am

https://www.invest...1709140700046938Q/

BE11:46am

Tad weak against consensus, which had already anticipated improved sales.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

The main news is that improved sales don't drop through to the bottom line because the grocery industry has a margin problem.

PM11:46am

hmm, that's interesting

BE11:48am

It is. We've talked in previous shows here about how the big four supermarkets did well for a few decades by taking share from the smaller operators, then when that soft underbelly was expended they hit problems.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

That remains the overarching theme here, I'd suggest, and it plays out via the H2 guidance. Have Cazenove to summarise the figures.

BE11:49am

Financial highlights:
2Q LFL in line at +2.6%; 2-Y stack LFL accelerates to +4.6% from +3.7% in 1Q;
Total sales up 4.8% YoY to £8.42bn;
PBT bang in line at £177mn, up 13% YoY;
EPS up 15% YoY to 5.79p;
FCF of £352mn included further £102m improvement in operating working capital and £93m of
disposal proceeds (post-dividend and pre-disposal proceeds, the business was cash flow positive,
generating £177m);
Net debt at £932bn (already below the less than £1bn FY target); and
£14m incremental profit from wholesale, services, interest and online, taking the total to £32m so far.

BE11:50am

Outlook increased for profits but implies muted FCF in 2H. Net debt guidance for FY below £1bn (not new); Annualised wholesale sales to exceed £700m (inc. tobacco) by the end of 2018 and wholesale supply sales to be more than £1bn in due course (not new); Incremental profit target increased to £75m–£125m, up from £50m–£100m (new); New profit guidance includes new wholesale supply agreement with McColl’s, expected to start making an initial profit contribution from 2018/19 (not new); ‘During the second half, we have planned for higher capital expenditure and onerous payments, lower property disposal proceeds and the seasonal benefit in working capital to unwind, so net debt is expected to remain broadly unchanged for the full year.’ This last comment should limit an eventual positive share price reaction, in our view.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

So ..... there we are. "Morrison trades on a FY18E PE of 19.4x vs Sainsbury on 11.7x and sector average of 14.3x" says Barclays, which is the other reason to argue that an improving sales trend is already in the price.

undefined
PM11:52am

Spire -- wow

11:52 am
PM11:52am

There's a lot of damage around today

PM11:52am

Spire Health

Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 255.70, down 54.2 (-17.49%), High: 274.20, Low: 230.40, Volume: 3.01m
11:52 am
PM11:53am

This e-referral stuff -- i thought this would be a big growth business

BE11:53am

No! No, my word no.

PM11:53am

Streamlining stuff at GPs

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Why not?

BE11:53am

The effect -- I'm not going to say the intention, but certainly the effect -- of e-referral has been to lengthen waiting lists.

BE11:54am

Which means less business goes to the NHS outsourcers like Spire.

11:54 am
PM11:54am

Oh dear, didnt appreciate that

PM11:55am

Jsut reading a snippet from Liberum..

PM11:55am

While the weakness earlier in the year is down to a general reduction in outsourcing by the NHS, in our view, the accelerated deterioration in recent months is likely to be driven by a recent memo from NHS England to all Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs, regional NHS entities) asking them to ensure that there is a clinical peer review of all referrals by GPs from September 2017.This policy is likely to cause substantial disruption to the referral process and lower overall volumes meaningfully as has been seen in recent pilot studies in Luton where referrals dropped 8%.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Yeah. E-referral is highly contentious. Opponents argue that it overloads the diagnostic side (which is cheap, relatively) to remove pressure from the more expensive treatment side.

BE11:56am

Once again, this is all known. Sellside's been on it for some time.

BE11:57am

Spire has had a bit of support thanks to the ever-present idea that Mediclinic will buy it.

11:57 am
PM11:58am

Which it hasnt

BE11:58am

Which it might! One day. And the rumours that it evaluates whether to stick or twist on its 30% investment come around on a bi-monthly basis. But it doesn't seem overly likely right now that Mediclinic would want another market where visibility's dropping off.

BE11:58am

Have Berenberg.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

NHS matters compounding: The relaxing of the waiting list targets have resulted in contract NHS revenues (around one-quarter of NHS revenues) falling by 12% in H1. The recent increased focus on GP referrals (the other three-quarters of revenues), discussed in our report dated 31 August, are placing pressure on e-referrals, which were up by 10% in H1.

BE11:59am

However, strong growth in self-pay: Self-pay accelerated further in July and August (+15%), and the company expects this to remain strong, particularly given the likelihood of patients having to wait longer for NHS treatment. It is placing more focus on this segment, with a new website and online marketing strategy.

BE11:59am

What does this mean? New EBITDA guidance implies H2 EBITDA contraction of 5% and 2017 EBITDA consensus falling by 7%. Furthermore, only two months into the new NHS trading environment, we see increased uncertainty for the remainder of the year and 2018.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

[L]owered guidance and increased uncertainty leads us to downgrade our rating to Hold from Buy. Our tentative new price target is 300p/share, based on a 10x EBITDA multiple and factoring in a mid- to high single-digit EBITDA downgrade for 2018.

undefined
PM12:01pm

Given then time -- we're just having a look round...

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

Bank of England?

PM12:01pm

Sterling Rocket

BE12:02pm

BOE MAJORITY SEES SCOPE FOR STIMULUS REDUCTION IN COMING MONTHS

12:01 pm
PM12:02pm

Relative Rocket

BE12:02pm

Knock it off, BOE. I need to flip a mortgage.

BE12:02pm

In terms of stuff we've not mentioned ...............

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Stagecoach -- sorry, I had a scratch around and have nothing whatsoever. Though if anyone want enlighten me on why it seems to be a ROTR favourite, do go ahead.

BE12:04pm

@Lefevre, on McCarthy & Stone ....

BE12:04pm

Goldman downgrade. Back to neutral.

12:04 pm
McCarthy & Stone PLC (MCS:LSE): Last: 145.86, down 9.14 (-5.90%), High: 154.00, Low: 142.94, Volume: 817.73k
BE12:05pm

We continue to believe the retirement homes market offers structural growth potential, given the favourable demographics and an untapped addressable market. However, we see continuing cyclical headwinds, with higher cost inflation and the secondary market remaining sluggish. We value the stock on 9x CY19E P/E (vs. 10x CY18E previously), which provides a 12-month price target of 175p (down from 210p on reduced estimates), implying minimal relative upside of c.14%. As such, we downgrade the stock to Neutral.

BE12:05pm

Recent data highlights that brownfield land inflation continues and that build cost inflation has accelerated, while the secondary market remains sluggish. We reduce estimates to reflect higher cost inflation and higher expected costs of WIP conversion into sales. We reduce our FY17/18/19 EPS forecasts by -8%-20%-20%. Since being added to the Buy List on September 9, 2016, the stock is down c.-15% vs. the FTSE World Europe up c.+18%, owing to ongoing cyclical headwinds in the secondary housing market driving negative earnings revisions.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

I do like the procedurally generated Goldman notes that automatically include how badly their recommendations go.

BE12:06pm

And that one's a real stinker.

undefined
12:06 pm
PM12:06pm

We're done!

PM12:07pm

Thanks for all that Bryce

PM12:07pm

And thanks for joining us on the right

12:07 pm
PM12:07pm

Tomorrow, hopefully, I will have full details of this Rabblefest we are organising So stay tuned

PM12:07pm

Bye for now

PM12:08pm

BornCynic -- forgot that. It's the fresh funding at Federated Wireless, which does mobile spectrum sharing

12:08 pm
PM12:08pm

Big fresh investors and Woodford still supporting

PM12:08pm

Bye

BE12:09pm

(@Forester: there was a rumour early last year that Souter was working on a take-private, but it seemed not to go anywhere and wasn't picked up by anyone. I note it for completeness rather than to revive the idea.)

12:09 pm
PM12:09pm

Bye properly nhow

PM11:30am

Scorchedfingers
